Is Da Vinciâ€™s masterpiece, the Mona Lisa, worth the hype?

By Emily Warner

Emily Warner (she/her) questions if the world-renowned â€˜Mona Lisaâ€™ is worthy of her popularity.

Fiddler on the Roof

Fiddler on the Roof showcased some great young talent, but for future productions of the same kind closer attention needs to be paid to the technical aspects.

The History Boys

'Pass the parcel on' is Hector's parting wisdom, and so I will: go and see it.

Deputy Editor's Picks.

Prison Fictions and Beluah are this week's picks

Best Book

Although many have set this book aside as one of Irving's worst, its merits are clear when the last page is turned

Sculpting Park Life

The Yorkshire Sculpture Park is an enthralling fusion of art and the natural world

Godspell

A few important contradictions and inconsistencies in the direction and performance of this production prevented it from plumbing the obsidian depths it intended to. It made me smile, and it made me think, but not always for the right reasons.

Takeover Festival 2012: Andrew Motion Reading

Motion moved us in his poetry and his sporadic emeralds of literary wisdom, but not as a speaker of prose.

Takeover Festival 2012: Verve 12

Although brilliant in demonstrating the great skill of its dancers, Verve 12 unfortunately fell short in forging a strong connection with the audience. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Chris Nash)

Stags and Hens

Whilst the acting of 'Stags and Hens' was commendable, the plot's lack of momentum failed to make the piece stand out

Review: Simon Amstell, Numb

Simon Amstell's current tour Numb is geeky, but all grown up

Takeover Festival 2012: Comedy Night

The Comedy Night was a varied affair; it offered mild amusement, but sadly no beer-spilling laughs.

Takeover Festival 2012: Wasted

Although Tempest only manages to skim over central issues, the production itself is thoroughly entertaining.

Pre-exam stress? Keep Calm at The Temple of a Thousand Bells

Take a break from exam revision to experience the tranquility of 'The Temple of a Thousand Bells' at York St Mary's.

Overworlds and Underworlds

The Leeds Canvas event was the Quay Brothers' creative interpretation of the cityscape for the 2012 Cultural Olympiad (Thumbnail credit The Quay Brothers under the Leeds Arches)

Takeover Festival 2012: Illusions

The audience were fully absorbed in the performance...Illusions encapsulates what it means to be loved, and to love another.

Takeover Festival 2012: Crave

Crave is an absorbing, albeit slightly disorientating, investigation into the depths of humanity.

In Pictures: Cecil Beaton

By James Bithell

Cecil Beaton's portraits of Queen Elizabeth II at the V&A.

Discovering Culture in Olympic Stadia

The exhibition curator of the Soane Museum, Dr Jerzy Kierkuc-Bielinski speaks to Celia Scruby about his up-coming summer exhibition Stadia: Sport and Vision in Architecture.

Best Book - Fatherland

Robert's Harris' 'Fatherland' is being reprinted in its 20th anniversary edition. Ciaran Rafferty recommends this as a foundling modern Classic.

A Park Bench with a Difference: Yorkshire Sculpture Park

You can't help but feel like Mary Lennox from Burnett's The Secret Garden here (Thumbnail credit York Sculpture Park)

Pygmalion

An uplifting performance punctuated with comedy, Pygmalion exposes the obvious tensions and unexpected similarities between classes in the late 19th century.

Birmingham Royal Ballet at York Theatre Royal

The Birmingham Royal Ballet provided a night of seamless dancing, colourful music and exceptionally taught buttocks.

Fourth Movement

The small details of set changes and other technical aspects could be improved. Nevertheless, Fourth Movement explored the issues of mental illness and marital breakdown with perceptive insight and talent from its actors

Out of my head: Paul Merton

Paul Merton's new tour was disappointing; both in the comedian's lack of convincing punchlines, and in his over-reliance on his fellow performers.

Review: URY O'Sullivan and Mawn

A few teething problems aside, O'Sullivan and Mawn's new radio show is genuinely brilliant.

Blue/Orange

Blue/Orange takes you deeper in to the human mind with every second.

Deathwatch

Jean Genet's one act play about three prisoners, Green Eyes, Lefranc and Maurice.

Painting Liberty in Cuba

The 'Miami Five' produce a series of artworks to highlight injustice

Best Book: Escape From Camp 14

Biography of Shin Dong-Hyuk, the only known person in history to have escaped from a North Korean gulag

The price of culture

Even if art organisations do decide to throw themselves into the deep end of the private sector, the funding could never be a guaranteed safety net.

Fiddler on the Roof

Fiddler on the Roof showcased some great young talent, but for future productions of the same kind closer attention needs to be paid to the technical aspects.

The History Boys

'Pass the parcel on' is Hector's parting wisdom, and so I will: go and see it.
